content.question: In which of the following measures is the beaming correct for the meter indicated?

choices.label: One measure in three-four. A single eighth note is followed by a group of two sixteenths and an eighth note beamed together, another group of two sixteenths and an eighth note beamed together, and finally two sixteenths beamed together.

One measure in three-four. A group of one eighth note and two sixteenths beamed together, a second group of one eighth note and two sixteenths beamed together, and a third group of one eighth note and two sixteenths beamed together.
One measure in three-four. An eighth note, two sixteenths, an eighth note, and two more sixteenths are all beamed together. This is followed by an eighth note and two sixteenths beamed together.
One measure in three-four. One eighth note and two sixteenths are beamed together, followed by a group of an eighth note, two sixteenths, an eighth note, and two sixteenths all beamed together.

content.answer: One measure in three-four. A group of one eighth note and two sixteenths beamed together, a second group of one eighth note and two sixteenths beamed together, and a third group of one eighth note and two sixteenths beamed together.

unit.text: 1: Music Fundamentals I - Pitch, Major Scales and Key Signatures, Rhythm, Meter, and Expressive Elements

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Use symbols and terms to describe features of rhythm in notated music, including meter, note values, and rhythmic patterns and devices.
